title: The Chaos Of War
opening: After making preparations at Garreg Mach, the Alliance army marches to Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. In response to the Alliance's movements, Emperor Edelgard orders her trusted retainer, Hubert, as well as the Death Knight, to the front lines to meet the Alliance army head-on. The two forces clash in the city streets.

Vastly outnumbered by Imperial forces, it becomes clear that a surprise attack, followed by a short and decisive battle, is the only path to victory. With this in mind, you stealthily approach Enbarr, the Imperial Capital.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: It's almost time to invade the Imperial capital. We still don't know where Rhea is, but if she's alive, she's likely in Enbarr. Hopefully we manage to find her without too much trouble.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: We need to save her quickly.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: I know, but if we're not careful she'll just be whisked away again.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: I wonder if she's alive.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: If the Empire has some reason to keep Rhea alive, then she's alive.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: I'm sure you must be anxious to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: I need to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: I understand. You need to see Rhea again so you can figure out who you really are.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: All I care about right now is saving her.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: Well, if that's what you want, I'll do my best to make it happen.

dialogue.speaker: Claude
dialogue.line: But we're going up against Edelgard here... It won't be so simple.

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Our next stop is the Imperial capital. We've sure come a long way.

dialogue.speaker: Raphael
dialogue.line: What're you talking about? This is Garreg Mach! It's where we started.

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: I didn't mean literally, Raphael. I was speaking symbolically!

dialogue.speaker: Lorenz
dialogue.line: My earnest desire to protect the Alliance has carried me this far. It will not fail me. I am sure the rest of you all have your own reasons to fight as well. Of course, I understand that the fight will not end until we defeat the Empire... And now the time has arrived at long last to march on the Imperial capital and defeat the emperor...

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: It really gets you thinking, doesn't it? We all come from different places and have different goals and dreams. But thanks to those two, we were all able to come together and overcome all sorts of challenges.

dialogue.speaker: Lysithea
dialogue.line: You are referring to Claude and the professor, I assume. Even within our own odd group, those two are particularly unusual.

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Oh! So, you are aware that you're odd!

dialogue.speaker: Lysithea
dialogue.line: Well... That's... It was simply a figure of speech. I am speaking about Claude and the professor right now!

dialogue.speaker: Marianne
dialogue.line: They're like the wind and the trees...

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Huh? Claude and the professor are? What does that even mean, and who is which?

dialogue.speaker: Marianne
dialogue.line: Oh, um... I was just thinking that if we're the birds, then those two are like the trees and the wind. The professor is a great tree that kindly embraces us and watches over us as we perch on its branches... And Claude is like the wind, pushing us forward as we soar across the open sky...

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: Hm. The metaphor about the professor is solid, but I think Claude just blows us around on a whim. Still, we owe him a lot.

dialogue.speaker: Ignatz
dialogue.line: I think that's beautiful, Marianne. I can really picture it. When the war is over, I'd love to paint a picture of those two. Oh! And of all the people we've fought with as well!

dialogue.speaker: Leonie
dialogue.line: You mean like a historical painting? I like that! Maybe our descendants will look at it a long, long time from now...

dialogue.speaker: Lorenz
dialogue.line: I must say, that piques my interest. I look forward to seeing how you portray my valiant efforts.

dialogue.speaker: Leonie
dialogue.line: When you put it that way, we may be witnessing one of the greatest events in Fódlan's history. It's a lot of pressure, but the sense of duty I feel is even stronger than the fear.

dialogue.speaker: Raphael
dialogue.line: I'm just happy to be here with all of you! I won't get scared, no matter what we face!

dialogue.speaker: Hilda
dialogue.line: We have our goal. Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. Let's get to work!

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: My friend! The reinforcements the lords sent are finally gathering. Truth be told, Fort Merceus would've made for a better base of operation. But that weird pillar of light changes things. It's pretty scary, honestly... I wonder what it is...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: The rage of the goddess.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Well, that is how the legend goes in Ailell. If it really was the rage of the goddess, let's do our best not to enrage her even further.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Some kind of magic.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Makes sense. But whatever it was, I've never seen destructive power quite like it. I wonder where it came from...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: A natural phenomenon.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: You think it's natural? What, the planet just up and decided to take a shot at the fort? I dunno, Teach.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Well, I guess pondering it is a waste of energy for now. Let's just get ready to move out. The capital is Edelgard's domain, so she has the advantage. It's going to be a tough battle.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: I was taught from a young age to believe that the creed of Seiros was just the way of the world. To question it never even occurred to me. But Claude and Edelgard are different. They challenge the common wisdom. Even defy it. It is uncomfortable to discard familiar assumptions. But that is an essential quality of the visionary. Indeed, true greatness must lie beyond common sense. Hmm, that's good. I should write that down.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: We're heading up to Enbarr next. I hope I make it back safe so I can tell my little sis about it! I hear they got a neat opera house there where Manuela used to perform. What was it called again?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Mitreflanc Opera Company.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Nah, that doesn't sound right!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Mittlefrank Opera Company.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Ah, that's the one!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Mildewplank Opera Company.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Nah, that doesn't sound right!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: My little sis always goes on about how much she'd like to see 'em perform. I know we can't see a show, but do you think we could at least see the building?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: We're about to put the finishing touches on this war. I wonder how Fódlan will look without the backdrop of death and destruction. I can't wait to see it! On the other hand, I'm terrified of what the future might hold. Who knows if I'll survive the assault on the capital?

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Invading the capital and smashing the Empire. I wonder if doing so could really end this war. Care to share your thoughts, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I think it'll end the war.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: You say that with such confidence. I want to believe that it's true.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't know.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Perhaps you feel similarly to me. The whole mess puts me on edge.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Although for now, better to focus my efforts on the fight at hand.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: If we can win this war, then Claude will be the king of Fódlan, and… Maybe he'll tear down the wall that separates Fódlan from the outside world.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Perhaps he will.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Perhaps he won't.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I know it's hard to imagine… But I really hope he does. It would be so much better if people could live together instead of apart. I might even be able to live an ordinary life in the world Claude envisions…

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Fighting in the capital! Ugh! And we're fighting against Edelgard! Double ugh! But with you leading us, Professor, I know we'll win. Yeah! Wahoo! Fighting! I'm a little scared, to be honest. I'm just shouting to relieve the tension, but I'll be fine.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: We're finally going to the capital. This will be my chance to avenge Captain Jeralt. Once we smash the Empire, I'm sure his soul will finally be able to rest in peace.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I think you're right.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Who can say for sure?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Monica killed Captain Jeralt for the Flame Emperor, and the Flame Emperor was Edelgard. I know that the future of all Fódlan rests on this battle. Nothing else is more important. But for me, this is personal. For Captain Jeralt's sake, I'm going to give it all I've got and more!

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Professor. At last, the end is nigh. I love the Empire. Part of me wants it to survive. But I know that is not reasonable. The Empire's time has come. What we need now is a mighty leader who can rebuild Fódlan and rule it as a single nation. Nonetheless, it saddens me that we will not have an Adrestian emperor…

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: They used to call Enbarr the city of Seiros... To assault it, together with the knights, is surreal. If Seiros were alive today, I wonder what she might make of our war... In Enbarr, there was once a Southern Church, and apparently a bishop was dispatched to it. A hundred years ago, the Southern Church became entangled in an insurrection. Until five years ago, the Empire and the church maintained a certain distance from one another.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: It's such a relief that we've made it this far without having to fight my father.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You'll have to face him at some point.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Hey, don't try and scare me!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It sounds like you're scared.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You bet I'm scared! The Imperial army hasn't lost a single battle with my father on the field!

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: If he turns up as a reinforcement during the assault, we might lose. I better make my peace with that.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Professor! My, um, my mother might be in the city. I don't have many good memories of her if I'm being honest, but she's dearer to me than my father. If you happen to see her, please make sure she's not caught up in all the fighting. She's only a civil servant, so hopefully she takes a cue from her Bernie and stays inside.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: The whole of the capital is going to be a battleground. The city has such a long heritage… Even so, perhaps it deserves to be reduced to ashes for once. But we can’t let the commonfolk get hurt. We should try to confine the damage to the noble section of town.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Five years ago...Edelgard said a thing to me. Brigid is a vassal of the Empire. But she also said I always have the freedom to be choosing whether I am with or not with her. I will become the ruler of Brigid. So she said I must make my own path. So now, my path and her path will be colliding.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: The Death Knight is no ordinary knight. I will prey upon him. I will quench my blade's thirst with his blood. His focus is on fighting you, I'm sure. But mine will be the last face he sees.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Those things appeared as soon as we got ourselves set up in Fort Merceus. Think what might have happened if they'd have hit us during the battle at Gronder Field. Assuming it was the work of the Imperial army...

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: So Enbarr, the Capital of the Empire. It's finally time. I never thought I'd live this long. It's like any battle, really--stay calm, stay focused. Don't give in to your enemy or your own fear.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You seem more serious than usual.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Hey, I'm always serious! When I'm chasing girls or preparing for battle, always serious. That's me...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We'll get through this together.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Striking down the Empire is my offering to His Highness. Heh, I left the Kingdom... What am I saying?

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: It's been so long since I've been to the Imperial capital. I used to go to the opera there with my mother and brother. I never thought my return would be like this...

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Enbarr… Never in my wildest dreams did I imagine I'd be returning like this. Of course, most of the nobles in the Empire make their home in the capital. In the Kingdom, all nobles live in their own domains. So if the capital is attacked, it doesn't necessarily affect them directly. What will happen to the Imperial nobles when their capital becomes a battlefield?

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Once this battle is over, what will become of Faerghus and Fódlan?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Peace will reign.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Peace, you say? It sounds so…foreign, so unattainable. But maybe, just maybe.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: What would you like to see happen?

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: My hope is for a world at peace. A world in which this present turmoil is a thing of the past—the stuff of legends.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: I believe those who survive the atrocities of war have a duty to create a new, better world. So the sooner we can stamp out such turmoil, the better. We must win, Professor. There is no alternative here. I won’t allow for anything else.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Rhea will be somewhere in the city. I wonder if she can sense us coming. If we are able to save her, then I expect you will learn many secrets that have hitherto been kept from you. Are you prepared for that?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I am.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Excellent.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't think I'm ready yet.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: That is unfortunate. Well, you must become ready.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: The battle will soon be upon us. Let us both be at our best for what is to come.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: I was born in Enbarr. My mother and father met in a church there. Not too long after, I was brought into the world. I do not understand how war can happen in such a precious place. It is most regrettable.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Enbarr's streets are paved with unhappy memories, Professor. I've avoided the damned place ever since I abandoned my nobility. Swore never to return. Now here we are. To return in this manner... Well, I can't say it is something I ever imagined.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: In the opera, actors came and went all the time. But the people behind the scenes would stay forever. I'll bet I'd know a few of them now, even after all these years.

conversation.speaker: Statement 1
conversation.line: I wonder if they've left the capital. I certainly hope so... Statement 2: They've probably left the capital by now. Although... I'm still worried about them.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Here we are, facing the final battle with the Empire. It's been a long, difficult struggle. We have to get Lady Rhea back! And we have to crush the Empire, in the name of Captain Jeralt. I don't know what comes next. But we can sort out those details later.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Looks like we're nearing the end of this struggle. I'm sure Lady Rhea is on tenterhooks waiting for me to swoop in and rescue her.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Probably.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: I was just kidding! Pay me no mind.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I doubt it.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Oof... You don't mince your words. Try being a bit more mindful of other people's feelings.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Lady Rhea's not waiting for me, I know, no matter how much I might wish she were. She's waiting for you.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Ten years ago, Dagda and Brigid attacked the Empire from the west. The final target was the capital. But they were countered at a port town, long before they reached their destination. I guess our attempt has been more successful than theirs, all things considered.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Whenever I think about how we'll be seeing Lady Rhea real soon, I get happy and really get cleaning! We'll get there for sure, right? We'll see her again?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We'll meet her for sure.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We don't know for sure.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: I got gotta believe Lady Rhea is waiting for us in the capital... We just have to find her.

conversation.speaker: Balthus
conversation.line: Nader the Undefeated… With a name like that, he's bound to put up a damn-good fight. Did you get a good look at Judith? She practically had hearts floating out of her eyeballs when she looked at Nader.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: She must be in love.

conversation.speaker: Balthus
conversation.line: You saw it too? Heh, I know that look well. She's got it bad. Honestly, they'd make a cute couple.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm not so sure about that.

conversation.speaker: Balthus
conversation.line: Pretty dense, aren't ya? Trust me, pal. No one's seen more heart-eyed women than this guy. She's got it bad.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's ridiculous.

conversation.speaker: Balthus
conversation.line: Pretty dense, aren't ya? Trust me, pal. No one's seen more heart-eyed women than this guy. She's got it bad.

conversation.speaker: Balthus
conversation.line: It makes all the sense. Even seasoned warriors aren't immune to love, pal.

conversation.speaker: Judith
conversation.line: That Nardel guy... or Nader, I suppose. It was all some trick, and we fell for it. Hmph. I don't think the nickname The Undefeated applies is he flees from us. Though... maybe he only got that name by running away. Can't be defeated if you run off, right?

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Momentum's really picking up for this final battle, huh? Even I'm starting to feel tense! Me! Enbarr's history goes back 1,400 years. That even predates the founding of the Empire. It's one of the sacred sites of the Seiros faith, so it's a pretty big deal. But hey, no need to worry about the monastery while you're fighting the final battle. I've got it covered! I'll defend it to my last!

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: There it is... Enbarr. The Imperial capital and the largest city in all of Fódlan.

intro.speaker: Judith
intro.line: It's not just big. This city was designed to protect the castle where the emperor lives. It's as though the city itself is a massive stronghold.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: What is the state of affairs in the town?

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: They surely noticed us approaching some time ago, and yet...

intro.speaker: Shamir
intro.line: Our scouts confirmed the citizens haven't been evacuated. They're being kept in town.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: I've got to hand it to Her Imperial Majesty. Using her citizens as a shield to protect the castle takes some resolve.

intro.speaker: Lysithea
intro.line: I suspect those mages will be lurking within as well...

intro.speaker: Shamir
intro.line: Troops deployed to other areas are also returning.

intro.speaker: Judith
intro.line: If we don't conquer the city quickly, things will get complicated fast.

intro.speaker: Seteth
intro.line: We can't search until we conquer the city. Let's focus on the fight for now.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: We've kept the Empire waiting long enough. Onward!

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: We were told Hubert would be leading the enemy forces, but the Death Knight's also with them. We'll have to take care of both of them, but we won't have time to mop up all the enemy units. We'll have to split up and take them on at the same time, or risk being overrun by their reinforcements.

battle.speaker: Imperial Soldier
battle.line: It's here! The Crest of Flames banner! There! On the other side of the canal!

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Uninvited guests, I see. Heh. Let's ensure they receive a warm welcome. Ready the artillery. Prepare to attack. Rocks, arrows, magic - rain death upon the enemy until they are silent as the grave. Reinforcements will fly in shortly. Defend the heavy weapons until they arrive.

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Our first wave of reinforcements is here. It will not be long until the next.

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: Reinforcements?! That was quick... We can't hang around or they'll just keep coming. We'll have to capture the artillery. We can turn them against their reinforcements...

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: We have reinforcements coming in from another direction. Deploy them as soon as they arrive.

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: OK! Just Hubert left to deal with...

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: We are taking heavy losses. We need more troops...

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: Well done, everyone! Now we can break through into Enbarr! We need to hurry up and attack the palace to block Edelgard's movements!

boss.speaker: Claude
boss.line: It's over, lapdog. Your military rule is at its end.

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: For every step you take along that path, our thorns will cut into your heels.

boss.speaker: Claude
boss.line: Ooh, that sounds painful. I'll have to wear thicker soles for the march.

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: If your boots are too heavy, you won't be able to lift your feet. But enough prattle.

boss.speaker: Seteth
boss.line: You will not escape, Death Knight. Today you will be unmasked!

boss.speaker: Death Knight
boss.line: My true identity has no value.

boss.speaker: Seteth
boss.line: I will be the judge of that, once I've seen your face.

boss.speaker: Flayn
boss.line: So it's you, Death Knight! Remember me?!

boss.speaker: Death Knight
boss.line: You again. Here to lose more blood?

boss.speaker: Flayn
boss.line: Never! You will not lay a hand on me ever again!

boss.speaker: Claude
boss.line: Hey, how long's it been? Five years? Who'd have thought you'd end up an Imperial general...

boss.speaker: Claude
boss.line: Heh. As antisocial and unhinged as ever, I see.

boss.speaker: Mercedes
boss.line: I came here to get you! Let's return together, Emile!

boss.speaker: Death Knight
boss.line: Leave! The place of your death is not here!

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: We've made it this far... Somehow. Edelgard is probably looking down on us from somewhere in that castle.

end.speaker: Leonie
end.line: I wonder if she's panicking or just smiling smugly...

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: From this point on, she'll be giving it her all too. Expect her to be tougher than the last time we fought. This battle will settle things once and for all. We'll attack as soon as everyone is ready.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Huh? Is that you, Dedue?!

end.speaker: Dedue
end.line: I heard the Alliance's army has entered the city. I've been searching for you ever since.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: How long have you been in Enbarr?

end.speaker: Dedue
end.line: I arrived not long after the battle at Gronder Field. I am here to kill Edelgard.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What are you doing in Enbarr?

end.speaker: Dedue
end.line: I'm waiting for a chance to kill Edelgard. I have not yet been blessed with the opportunity.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Well, if you want to fight alongside us, we'd be more than happy to have you.

end.speaker: Dedue
end.line: We fight for different objectives. I swore to offer Edelgard's head to His Highness. But... Should I fail, I will have no choice but to entrust that mission to you. This is the information I have gathered during my time in hiding here. It includes details about the inside of the castle.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I appreciate this, but... What do you plan to do? Don't tell me you plan to do alone?

end.speaker: Dedue
end.line: I've done what I came here to do. Farewell.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Hey! Wait! He's gone. He's just as hard to understand as his liege was.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: The time has finally come, my friend. Once we win this fight, the Empire will fall...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What will become of Fódlan?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: What will become of it? Well, that's for us to decide, isn't it?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What will we do about Fódlan?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: The subject is heavy on my mind.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Odd as it sounds, I believe the forces responsible for destroying Fódlan are also responsible for protecting the livelihood of its citizens. Everything, even the land itself, has been harmed by the chaos of war. Restoring it will be no easy feat. To do that, the first thing we need to think about is a new ruling system for all of Fódlan.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: The Alliance lords could divide the territory.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: No, I don't think that would work. The western half of the continent has little connection to the Alliance. Any attempt to force dominion on them would breed rebellion. The world would slide back into war once again.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: We could unify Fódlan as one nation.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: As usual, we're on the same page. I was thinking the same thing.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Even if the Alliance lords and any remaining influential nobles were to divide up dominion of all of Fódlan... They would simply pursue their own interests. Another war would be inevitable. That's why there needs to be a powerful ruler who stands above them all and unifies Fódlan as one nation.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: You should be that ruler, Claude.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: If it means I can lead Fódlan to a better future, I wouldn't mind that at all.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: We must search for a new ruler.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: A new ruler, huh? I think I've got someone in mind.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I should be that ruler.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: My friend... Do you really mean that?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: My dreams await in a future where Fódlan is no longer ravaged by war. There are things I want to see with you some day. I'll keep thinking about the best way to achieve that goal. Whatever we decide to do, we can't do it until we defeat the Empire. Fódlan can't welcome a new dawn until we win the war. Let's prepare as best we can.
